page.title: 05LANDSCAPE AND BUILDINGS
page.content: The area is dominated by the village of SENNYBRIDGE (PONT SENNI).This is not as old as the adjacent village of Defynnog but grew in the 19th century as the place where the Neath and Brecon railway met the turnpike road (now A 40) in the Usk valley. This became a convenient place to hold a market and it is this role which is still the most important function of the village. The railway has long since gone, but the cattle mart is conveniently situated close to the main road. The importance of the mart is further exemplified by the fact that this small village has no fewer than 3 branches of banks (admittedly only open for a few hours each week). The vilage is nearly all spread along the sides of A 40 and the original route of A 4067 to Defynnog.
